duty.title: Should Statements — Running in Shackles
duty.description: This article explores how cognitive distortions shape our view of reality and affect mental health. We focus on understanding and loosening “should” statements to cultivate a more mindful, flexible, and joyful outlook.

texts: We now know that a person’s psychological state is tightly linked to their thinking. In depression, it can feel like looking at the world through gray-tinted glasses—everything seems duller than through a clear lens.
Depression tilts perception away from objectivity, adding biases that don’t support mental health or optimism. Today we’ll look at some of these patterns.
These are cognitive distortions—thinking errors that are central in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy.
First, a quick note on cognition: it’s our capacity to perceive, interpret, and process information from the senses.
It enables us to take in, understand, and remember the world around us—and to make decisions and solve problems.
In short, cognition is the set of mental processes that includes thoughts, images, and mental representations.
Cognitive distortions are thinking errors that arise during information processing and interfere with sound reasoning.
They’re misinterpretations of events—moments when our view of reality doesn’t match the facts.

quote.text: If our thinking gets stuck in distorted symbolic meanings, illogical reasoning, and mistaken interpretations, we become blind and deaf to reality.
quote.author: Aaron Beck

texts: In our app, we highlight the key cognitive distortions; you can review them on the Automatic Thoughts Diary page.
In this course, we’ll examine three common ones. Let’s start with “should” statements.
“Should” statements are rigid beliefs about what must or must not happen. They create demands toward ourselves, others, and the world.
This distortion is extremely common: we build a rigid model of how life must be, and when reality doesn’t match it, strong negative emotions follow.
Examples of “should” statements:
I must be liked by everyone
I must not make mistakes
I must keep everything under control
A man must provide for the family
People around me must be attentive and polite

The word “should” implies there’s no alternative—even though alternatives often exist. “Should” statements create an illusion of a perfect world, and stepping outside that illusion confronts us with a harsher reality.
This distortion narrows our choices, setting a condition: either act a certain way or feel guilty and distressed.
Why is this harmful? With adaptive thinking, the gap between expectations and reality isn’t catastrophic, because we understand not every wish can be fulfilled.
With maladaptive thinking, however, our internal model outweighs reality. The model is treated as absolute—and reality as mistaken.

test.question: Why are cognitive distortions harmful?
answers: They prevent an objective view of reality
They make success in life impossible

texts: How do you work with this distortion? Step one is awareness. Track your thoughts and write them down whenever they include “should,” “must,” or “have to.” Notice how these words affect your emotions.
Step two is challenge. Ask yourself, “Why do I believe it must be exactly this way?” and “What evidence says it has to be so?”
Step three is alternatives. Replace “should” with “I’d like” or “it would be good if.” For example:
“It would be good if my partner did what I think is right. But they’re entitled to their own view of reality.”
“I’d like to be flawless. But I’m human, and I’m allowed to be imperfect.”
In closing, practice noticing and softening “should” statements in everyday life. Start by observing your thoughts and reactions in different situations.
Pay attention to moments when you use “should,” “must,” or “have to,” and ask questions that help you challenge these automatic thoughts.

guilt.title: The Shadow of Guilt: The Link Between Guilt and Depression
guilt.description: The article explores the connection between guilt and depression, highlighting how excessive or unfounded guilt can contribute to the development of depressive states. The authors distinguish between healthy and unhealthy guilt, noting that the former can motivate positive change, while the latter often leads to self-isolation and a deepening of depression. Strategies are offered to build self-awareness and address unhealthy guilt to improve emotional well-being.

texts: Excessive guilt often goes unnoticed as a symptom of depression, even by many psychologists and psychotherapists.
Yet excessive guilt is a common symptom of depression, and its intensity often tracks the disorder’s severity.
Depression accompanied by guilt can convince a person that they are unworthy of life, that they have caused someone irreparable harm, or that others would be better off without them.
The relationship between guilt and depression is bidirectional, meaning either condition can give rise to the other.
Frequent experiences of guilt can contribute to the development of a depressive state.
It’s hard to maintain well-being when you keep blaming yourself for everything—your problems, circumstances, and relationships with others.
This stance toward oneself, the accompanying mindset, and the guilt that comes with it can persist for years, sometimes for a lifetime.
For various reasons, a person may conclude that they failed in a situation when they “should” have succeeded—or that they should have acted, felt, or experienced it differently.
If this conclusion becomes reinforced—if guilt becomes a frequent “visitor”—a full depressive episode may develop.
Depression can also be a reaction to “chronic problems.” A person tries to cope with them but, for various reasons, may lack the experience and skills needed to resolve them.
They blame themself for this and sink into depression.
So, guilt is an emotion you experience when the following thoughts arise:
I did something I should not have done (or failed to do something I should have), and this conflicts with my moral standards or sense of justice.
Such “wrong behavior” proves that I am a bad person (or that I have a tendency to cause harm, that my character is flawed, etc.).
In other words, a belief in one’s own “defectiveness” often underlies guilt.
When depressed, a person often feels guilty and blames themself for nearly everything: from having no energy or motivation to being unable to feel joy or pleasure.
They may also blame themself for becoming depressed, treating it as a sign that something is “wrong” with them.
Loved ones may also blame them, accusing them of laziness and urging them to stop “making a fuss,” which only worsens the depressive state.
Depressive guilt can arise even in situations that do not violate moral norms, making a person feel guilty where no guilt is warranted.
Under the influence of depression, a person may focus only on mistakes, overlooking strengths and achievements.
This raises a question: is feeling guilty always bad?
The answer is no. Guilt can be useful because it helps us recognize and correct mistakes and supports social norms and cooperation.
Guilt serves as a moral compass closely linked to our conscience.

quote.text: There is no greater evil than guilt.
quote.author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

texts: However, when guilt becomes excessive or unfounded, it begins to harm our emotional and physical well-being.
Whereas healthy guilt motivates positive change, depressive guilt often leads to isolation and withdrawal.
In some cases, it can even drive a person toward self-punishment.
To better understand the difference between healthy and unhealthy guilt, consider the following examples of each:
Healthy guilt
A person recognizes that they acted wrongly, yet also understands that, at the time, they had no real way to act differently.
The circumstances then—limited knowledge, lack of experience, strong emotions—didn’t allow another course of action.
For instance, they might not have known the action was wrong, were swept up in intense feeling, or lacked the experience to foresee the consequences.
In other words, at that moment they couldn’t have been better than they were. Now they’ve changed, gained perspective, and feel shame and pain about what they did and who they were then.
In this case, the person treats themself with understanding: they recognize their motives and reasons and see what was missing that could have prevented it.
They distinguish what can be changed to reduce the chance of recurrence and what lies outside their control. This guilt isn’t theatrical; it doesn’t turn into self-flagellation.
The experience is sober, though painful—in essence, sincere remorse grounded in humility and acceptance.
Unhealthy guilt
A person also understands that they acted wrongly. But unlike the first case, they believe that, at the time of the misdeed, they could have acted differently.

They believe they could have overcome their at-the-time understanding, lack of knowledge, experience, or emotional state—an unacknowledged refusal to accept the real, inevitable limits of that moment.
This gives rise to the anguished cry: “How could I?!”
How could I fail to meet expectations, sink so low, make mistakes, or lose control over something or someone?
I could have acted differently—I had the chance—but I didn’t. How awful! So I must not be in control. That’s impossible; I simply didn’t try hard enough, or I’m just a bad person.
Self-compassion isn’t allowed here: if you “could have,” then reasons don’t matter—full stop.
The person repeatedly revisits what has already happened, injuring themself again and again.
Using the following questions, you can quickly tell whether what you feel is healthy remorse or self-destructive, distorted guilt.
Ask yourself:
Did I truly do something “bad” or “unjust”? Did I cause harm knowingly and intentionally? Or am I unreasonably demanding perfection, omniscience, and omnipotence from myself?
Am I labeling myself a bad or unworthy person because of this? Do my thoughts contain cognitive distortions such as magnification, overgeneralization, and so on?
How realistic are my regret and remorse? Do they arise from empathic understanding of the negative consequences of my actions?
Am I willing to learn from my mistakes? What steps am I taking? Am I thinking about how to repair the situation?

incrimination.title: Self-Esteem in the Depths of Depression: A Path to Self-Acceptance and Inner Balance
incrimination.description: This article examines how depression affects self-esteem, showing how negative self-perception intensifies depressive symptoms and stands in the way of a fulfilling life. Drawing on case examples and expert guidance, it offers practical steps to move beyond self-criticism and strengthen inner balance. It’s a practical guide for anyone seeking to build confidence and change their life for the better.

texts: One of the typical symptoms of depression is a tendency toward self-blame, feelings of inferiority, and a sense of having little worth or significance.
People often apply labels like “failure” or “worthless,” seeing themselves as fundamentally bad.
More severe depression is typically associated with lower self-esteem. You’re not alone: research by Aaron Beck shows that over 80% of people with depression experience feelings of worthlessness.
Your self-image shifts markedly in depression: you may feel inadequate, down, lonely, and deprived. You criticize yourself—your actions, abilities, and future.
Self-criticism often takes forms such as:
Self-blame — “It’s all my fault.”
Labeling — “I’m so stupid.”
Self-hatred — “I can’t stand myself anymore.”
Self-doubt — “Nothing will work out for me.”
Living with a list like that is, at the very least, hard. In depression, a person may criticize and put themself down endlessly—often without even noticing.
Naturally, this affects emotions, mood, self-regard, and your outlook on life as a whole.
That’s why working on self-esteem matters so much. By reducing self-criticism, you can influence other depressive symptoms as well. So let’s start with your self-esteem.

quote.text: Low self-esteem is like driving through life with your hand-brake on.
quote.author: Maxwell Maltz

texts: Poor self-esteem is a magnifying glass that turns every mistake or setback into a catastrophe.
Consider this dialogue between a person with depression and a psychologist:
Catherine, why did your supervisor’s remark trigger such intense, negative feelings? Is it truly that catastrophic?
Yes, it was awful, because I looked like such a fool.
Let’s suppose you did look that way. What does that mean to you?
It means my boss thought I was stupid.
And even if that’s what your boss thought, what follows from that?
Then I don’t deserve to work at this company.
And if you truly don’t deserve it, what would that mean?
It means I’m a nobody who will never achieve anything and will spend the rest of my life mopping floors somewhere.
This example shows how a minor comment from a manager is taken as proof of Catherine’s worthlessness and used to predict a bleak future.
When we’re depressed, small missteps feel tragic. In that state, we often struggle to think realistically and logically.
Instead, we become convinced of our own inadequacy and uselessness—and may even convince others of it by highlighting our flaws and insisting on our incompetence.

First, it’s important to recognize that your worth cannot be earned. Success can bring pleasure, but not lasting happiness. Self-esteem built solely on achievements is pseudo-esteem—it isn’t realistic.
Many successful yet unhappy people with depression also see themselves as worthless. There are well-known public figures who seemed to have everything—career, money, fame, talent—yet died by suicide.
Most people living with depression are actually capable, often talented, attractive, interesting, and surrounded by care and love.
But that doesn’t help if there is no self-respect or self-regard. Your sense of inherent worth largely shapes how you feel.
A crucial step is to pay close attention to what you think and say about yourself.
The next time you insist you’re unfit for something or judge yourself harshly—your actions or your experience—look for actual evidence. Often, the “evidence” doesn’t hold up.
Second, replace self-criticism with self-correction.
When you’re learning something new—say, a new language—a good teacher doesn’t shame you or call you stupid for not knowing the tenses.
That would be a poor teacher with an ineffective method. You likely wouldn’t want to learn—or be able to learn—under those conditions.
Unfortunately, we often become that poor teacher to ourselves: criticizing instead of correcting.
So try asking yourself: Is there a better way to do this? How could I implement it? What do I still need to learn?
Third, each time you criticize yourself, imagine speaking to someone else in exactly the same way. Would you be that harsh with them?
Apply the same standards to loved ones and friends that you apply to yourself—honestly. As you try this, you’ll see just how unfair your self-criticism really is.
Your self-esteem is a key driver in setting life goals and pursuing them.
With low self-esteem, you underestimate your abilities and deny yourself the right to happiness.
To change the situation, you need to change thinking habits and behaviors—taking small steps toward healthy self-esteem, accepting setbacks, and noticing even the smallest wins.
We want to support you on this challenging path—to offer hope, help you choose manageable steps, and keep your focus on them. In the next chapters, we’ll walk through several effective techniques.
